name: Þjófafoss - The Thieves' Waterfall
description: Þjófafoss, translating to "Thieves' Waterfall" or "Thief Falls," is a historically significant and visually impressive waterfall on Iceland's longest river, the Þjórsá, which stretches approximately 230 kilometers (143 miles) from its glacial source to the Atlantic Ocean. Located in South Iceland on the eastern edge of the Merkurhraun lava field beneath the imposing bulk of Mount Búrfell, Þjófafoss bears a dark and memorable name derived from Iceland's harsh medieval justice system—thieves convicted of crimes were traditionally executed here by drowning in the waterfall's turbulent pool, making the site both a natural wonder and a reminder of Iceland's stern historical code. The waterfall itself features multiple channels of milky glacial water cascading over dark volcanic rock ledges in a broad, powerful display that spans the full width of the substantial Þjórsá river. However, visitors should understand that Þjófafoss exists in a state of dramatic flux due to modern hydroelectric operations: the flow can vary from a thunderous full-river cascade to a reduced trickle or even complete absence of water, depending on the operational needs of Landsvirkjun's Búrfellsvirkjun hydroelectric power station which has operated at the base of Mount Búrfell since 1972. This power plant diverts a large proportion—sometimes nearly all—of the Þjórsá's water flow for electricity generation.
address: Þjórsá River, Route 32, South Iceland (near Mount Búrfell)
